node.title: Children will soon be eligible for a COVID-19 vaccine. But what if parents disagree?
node.alt: Primary school kids carrying backpacks on a rainy winter day.
node.description: Now that children younger than 12 are eligible for a COVID-19 vaccine, some say we could see an increase in Family Court matters. But the courts have already put measures in place to prioritise such disputes, should they arise.
node.content:
["As more and more adult Australians receive a COVID-19 vaccine, the conversation is increasingly turning to the issue of protecting children from the disease.", "In early December, Australia's Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) provisionally approved the Pfizer vaccine for children between five and 11 years of age.", "Now, the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI) has provided its recommendations around the program.", "The rollout will begin on January 10, with bookings opening in late December\u00a0\u2014\u00a0a significant step forward for the nation's fight against the virus.", "\"This will bring great relief to so many mums and dads, who now have a choice on what's best for their kids,\" Prime Minister Scott Morrison said.", "\"They can have peace of mind knowing this has the tick from the best medical regulators in the world.\"", "But while the majority of Australians will welcome\u00a0ATAGI's decision, it has sparked concerns among parents who are in conflict over the issue with their ex-partners.", "
Vaccines further dividing separated couples
", "", "
Vaccines for children aged five to 11 are expected to be approved ahead of January next year.(ABC News: Freya Michie)
", "Lucy (not her real name)\u00a0was confronted with that predicament when her ex-partner started to speak out against vaccinations.", "Before that, the Canberra mother\u00a0said she had not known her former partner to be opposed to vaccines.", "So when the vaccine rollout began, they were quickly at loggerheads over how to act on behalf of one of their children, who was older than 12 and therefore eligible for a COVID-19 vaccine.", "Lucy said she suggested a meeting where the pair could discuss the matter, but that never eventuated.", "\"So I had no way of dialoguing with him on it ...\u00a0there was just nowhere\u00a0to go,\" she said.", "Lucy sought legal advice and was told she was within her rights to take her child to be vaccinated.", "She was told that even if her ex-partner sought an injunction with the Federal Court, it was likely they would rule in favour of vaccination anyway.", "She said she also sought advice from ACT Health and was told the same thing.", "But Lucy said it was a distressing situation for all involved.", "In the end, her ex-partner\u00a0did not intervene, but she said it was a difficult experience for herself and her child, who wanted to get vaccinated but was caught between parents with opposing views.", "\"It sent the relationship into a new low between us,\" she said.", "Lucy said her concerns had been raised once again since the TGA announced it had given provisional approval for children aged five to 11 to receive a vaccine from January 2022.", "Her younger child is in primary school, and would therefore soon be eligible.", "But Lucy remains fearful that her ex-partner will turn to the courts this time around.", "\"He can always go and represent himself and just fight it as long as he wants, and that's the fear...\u00a0the fear of actually entering into a legal battle, because that is so expensive,\" she said.", "
Courts must weigh the relative risks
", "", "
Children tend to suffer relatively mild symptoms when infected with the virus.(ABC News: Bianca Clare)
", "Like all Family Court matters, COVID-19 vaccines are likely to be a nuanced issue for the system\u00a0to tackle once children become eligible.", "While vaccines have been proven to prevent severe illness and death, the court is not required to consider society as a whole when deciding on a case, only the wellbeing of the child.", "Di Simpson, an accredited specialist in family law based in Canberra, said it was likely there would be more cases involving a disagreement over COVID-19 vaccinations\u00a0in court if vaccines were mandated for those under 12.", "But she said it was usually the case that parents in that situation would be strongly encouraged to seek a resolution before the court was forced to intervene.", "Currently, it is legal for one parent to take their children to be vaccinated without needing the approval of the other.", "But for those couples who have a standing disagreement that can't be resolved, the next step is usually mediation.", "\"It's not unusual to have a dispute between parents about whether or not their children should be vaccinated,\" Ms Simpson said.", "But when it comes to a public health emergency like the COVID-19 pandemic, the issue may become slightly more complicated.", "Ms Simpson said while judges usually ruled in favour of vaccination, ruling with the best interests of the child in mind given\u00a0the relatively mild impact of the virus on young people could make it a more nuanced issue.", "While\u00a0diseases such as rubella, measles and whooping cough are potentially fatal for children, COVID-19 is unlikely to be as severe.", "\"Parents are entitled to say, 'this child means everything to me, and I have an obligation to keep this child safe',\" she said.", "Ms Simpson said court\u00a0decisions could\u00a0depend on the potential side effects of the vaccines for children when they were inevitably approved by the regulator.", "\"There are some\u00a0areas of uncertainty\u00a0and there are credible arguments that a parent might run about just being fearful about risk,\" she said.", "\"And so a judge in that instance would be doing what they often have to do, which is a risk assessment.", "But she said given the cost of the court process, the ideal scenario was to have parents agree before it reached that point, by seeking out mediation.", "
COVID-19 matters raise the issue of 'urgency'
", "", "
Family lawyer Di Simpson says judges will have to weigh the risks when determining whether a child should be vaccinated.(Unsplash: Kylie Sikkema)
", "For Kerri (not her real name),\u00a0the choice was simple as to whether to get vaccinated.", "But for her sister, it was more complicated. Her sister wanted to be vaccinated and to ensure her children received the vaccination too, but her former husband disagreed.", "She said her sister's ex-husband opposed other medical interventions, in addition to COVID-19 vaccines, before the pandemic was declared.", "\"It's taken two-and-a-half years, they still haven't had a hearing, they just get pushed off to mediation and then sort of given future dates,\" Kerri said.\u00a0", "\"So far, it has\u00a0cost $25,000.\"", "Kerri said the stress of the situation\u00a0had\u00a0taken a toll on her sister's health, as the situation continued\u00a0without resolution.", "Meanwhile, she said both the children want to be vaccinated, and both Kerri and the children's mother\u00a0are concerned they won't be permitted access to certain activities with other children\u00a0without a vaccine certificate.", "The federal government has already mandated that Australians must be vaccinated in order to travel overseas.", "\"She desperately wants to get them vaccinated on the basis of public health,\" Kerri said.", "But while Kerri's sister has been forced to spend years going through the system to resolve her dispute with her ex-husband over medical decisions, the process is a little more simple when it comes exclusively to COVID-19 vaccines.", "The\u00a0Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia has introduced a court list entirely for\u00a0matters related to the virus, which are prioritised due to the ongoing public health concerns.", "\"That would be an obvious pathway for someone to make an urgent application if there was a dispute about the vaccination\u00a0for a child,\" Ms Simpson said.", "Kerri said she had contacted health authorities for advice on behalf of her sister, and was told she was not the first person to call in about the issue.", "\"The advice was consistent all the way along,\u00a0[they said] 'we can't give advice on that, you have to talk to a family\u00a0solicitor'.\"", "She said she hoped the matter\u00a0became simpler for families and did not drag out like it had for her sister's family.", "\"I think in this situation, there's a certain urgency because it is a public health issue,\" Kerri said.", "\"And I know governments have put a lot of effort into trying to protect the safety of the community and to address the pandemic.\"", "She said it had been hard to watch her sister suffer.", "\"The whole court case over the years has been very stressful, and now [COVID] is just kind of like the icing on the cake either way,\" she said.", "\"It's that feeling of powerlessness.\""]
